title: Five Hour Sunset
description: It's day one, so not a huge number of photos, most of the day was spend building this site while chasing the setting sun across the Atlantic en route to Rio (site improvements in the coming days). Photos can be found down below, I likely won't upload every day while other days I might pop some bonus text content under the photos. Those expecting beautiful prose turn back now.

title: Copacabana
description: Checked into the Pura Vida Hostel and found out a few fun things today: #1 Universal travel adaptors don't work in Brazil. #2 Chase debit cards don't work at ATM's in Brazil. #3 My sweat glands work really well in Brazil, it is humid af. For more revelations (and maybe that image of south america replaced with something else) tune in tomorrow.

title: The Botanical Gardens
description: The weather was a bit questionable today so I went for a big ol' stroll to: visit Ipanema beach, have lunch where The Girl from Ipanema was written (thanks for the recommendation Julio!) and see the botanical gardens. Turns out I'm a terrible wildlife photographer and missed all the monkeys and cool birds. Finished the day with happy hour and samba class back at the Pura Vida.

title: Caipirinhas & Beach Volleyball
description: It's been 30¬∞ and sunny for the last 2 days so I've barely left the beach and rarely brought my phone with me so not many good photos, sorry! I'm starting to think that portion control isn't a common phrase in Brazil as every meal is absolutely behemoth. Also I found a table in the shape of a butt, perfect for bottomless drinks hour.

title: Thunderstorms & Rugby
description: The thunderstorms in Rio are intense! I thought a bomb had gone off near my hostel last night. With weather like this the only thing to do was find an Irish pub (they really are everywhere) and watch the rugby. Also destroyed the competition at karaoke, although there is no photo or video proof so you'll just have to trust me. 10 points to anyone who can guess the flag.

title: Morro Dois Irm√£os
description: A group of us went for a morning hike up the two brothers, which stand over the west side of Rio and give you an unreal view of the city and the largets favela in Latin America. A motorbike ride through the favela gets you to the start of the hike (sorry mum) and after an hour or two of sweaty jungle climbing you get a pretty sweet reward for your efforts.

title: Couple Days of Culture
description: Visited the museum of tomorrow and saw the sites up in the centre of town with a couple of friends. Ooh hostel friends. Also tried to go visit Christ the Redeemer but they closed it down for the day due to a storm toppling some trees, so going back to do that in a couple of days, hopefully with better weather.

title: Ipanema
description: Spent the last few days at the Mango Tree in Ipanema. Great place for parties & meeting people, would definitely recommend. I also went up to see the Christ the Redeemer statue, which actually looked really cool looming out of the clouds, shame about the non-existent view from the top but I did get to see some monkeys. Time now for a hungover 4 hour bus ride

title: Paraty
description: The next stop on the journey is Paraty, a colourful little colonial town about 4 hours from Rio. Shoutout to Sarah for the recommendation, it's a really beautiful place, the weather is great, the hostel has a pool and the beer is cold so life is good.

title: Jungle Treehouse
description: So this stop was purely based on a recommendation from KK, she big shoutout to her because the Remo Hostel is pretty sweet, it's situated on a mountainside in the middle of the jungle with amazing views out towards the ocean. It was beautiful when I arrived but has rained consistently since, the clue was in the name rainforest I suppose. Anyway seeing as nobody else speaks any English this should be a good time to learn some Portguese.

title: Ilha Grande
description: Arrived on the Big Island, it's one of those places that I knew I was going to enjoy as soon as I arrived. Really laid back place with loads of places to eat, drink and meet people as well as some amazing scenery. I checked into my awesome, if somewhat confusing, chapel room (see below) at the Mambembe hostel, met a couple of girls and went out for drinks, turns out one of them grew up in West Byfleet, small world, huh. Continued below...
additionalContent:
Despite a decent hangover from a heavy night on the caipirinhas I thought a little hike would be a good shout for day 2. What I didn't expect was for the hike to be a 5 hour slog through the jungle and for it to be 31¬∞, I also took the smart decision to take a ‚Äúshortcut‚Äù based on a comment left on a message board, which took me off the path and down a steep narrow gulley I affectionately named Spider Alley, only for the path to become a river thanks to all the rain over the past few days. That of course meant I had to hike back up The Alley, so lesson learned there. 
 To be honest it was worth it in the end for the views, the waterfalls and the completely deserted beach surrounded by two rivers as they reached the sea. So if you're ever on Ilha Grande I'd recommend the Dois Rios hike, but maybe wear something other than white trainers unless you want them painted brown. After hiking the 12km back to Abr√£ao, I rewarded myself with a massive steak on the beach at a restaurant as inventively named as the island itself: Steak & Beach.

title: Ciao Brazil
description: I spent my last few days on Ilha Grande laying on the beach and paddle boarding during a rare spell of good weather, alongside some caiparinha & beer fueled late night hostel debates on hot topic issues. Pretty sure I know less about Gaza than before we started. Back in Rio today enjoying the last of the sun before I fly to Argentina tomorrow.

title: Hola Argentina
description: Buenos Aires is cold and wet üòÖ. It's about 15 degrees colder here than it was when I took off from Rio, good job I only packed a single fleece for this trip! Oh well the restaurants are warm and the steak dinner and bottle of wine I had last night cost all of ¬£12. It's mainly just been flights and hotels for the last couple days so no good photos. But there's plenty of the sun in the forecast for this week so that should change soon, I'm staying in Recoleta for the next few days so if anyone has recommendations let me know.

title: Recoleta
description: I love Buenos Aires. It's got a very relaxed vibe and feels very European when you're seated at a little cafe in the sunshine having lunch. I did the customary tour of the Recoleta Cemetery while the weather was overcast on the first day. It's a really interesting mix of styles & architecture; it doesn't really feel like a graveyard at all. Since then, the sun has come out, so time has been spent exploring, eating empanadas, drinking beer, and sitting in the street watching Boca Juniors narrowly losing the Copa Libertadores final with what felt like every single other inhabitant of BA.

title: Palermo
description: My last couple of days in Buneos Aires were spent mainly in Palermo, enjoying the parks in the sunshine as well as the great food and wine in the center, I would definitely come back to BA. A group of us went to something called the Argentina Experience, where you try some of BA's favorite dishes, as well as doing a cocktail, empanada, and mat√© course. I ended up winning the creative empanada folding contest with a 4-leaf clover (definitely intended it to be that shape from the beginning, not just a way to get four fillings into one empanada). I'm writing this from the airport, waiting for my flight up to Puerto Iguazu, where it's 30+¬∞, to go see the falls.

title: Iguazu Falls
description: Had a great couple of days in Iguazu. It was blisteringly hot so standing in the spray from the largest waterfall system in the world was a pretty great place to be, pretty spectacular too, I can definitely see why it's one of the one of the world's new seven natural wonders. Also saw a load of cool wildlife I'd never seen before, in fact I'd never even heard of a coati or a nasua, I managed to snap a photo of a few of them but the capuchins were too quick for me. Thankfully we got off the ground early this morning before the thunderstorms began, so I'm back in BA now for a connecting flight to Mendoza.

title: Mendoza
description: Sorry for the wait on an update but Mendoza was pretty action packed and I never really found the time to do this. It was definitely my favourite place that I've visited so far, so shoutout to all of you who recommended it. The Gorilla Hostel in Mendoza is amazing and I met so many great people there who made the horseback riding, cycle wine tours and hungover days in the pool so much fun. In fact it was really hard to leave for Bariloche, especially knowing that it was 30¬∞ in Mendoza and 3¬∞ in Bariloche, but a small crew of us from the Gorilla are now safely checked in to Penthouse 1004 in Bariloche so watch out for photos from there in a few days time.

title: Bariloche
description: Four days in Bariloche flew by. The town is essentially a Swiss mountain village that has been dropped onto the Northern tip of Patagonia complete with chocolate shops, fondue restaurants and ski lifts. The weather here is pretty unpredictable and so is the scenery. The area around town seems to have parts of Nevada, Utah, California, Northern Scotland, New Zeland and of course Switzerland all stitched together. Continued below...
additionalContent: Yesterday 4 of us rented a car for the equiliviant of ¬£6 each (with petrol) and did a 12 hour round trip through the seven lakes to San Martin which was an amazing drive with it's own rally special stage to get to some of the lakes. Once we got to San Martin the clouds parted for a while so we had time to do a little hike on the cliffs surrounding the town/lake and then we found a lovely little restaurant for some fresh smoked lake trout sorrentinos. I'm currently writing this on a 6 hour bus through the Andes to Puerto Montt in Chile so I can fly further south into the heart of Patagonia to hike some pointy mountains (and yes it's one of the most beautiful bus rides I've ever taken).

title: Puerto Montt
description: Arrived in Puerto Montt after a long old bus from Bariloche. No complaints though, the bus was super comfortable; I had a spare seat next to me and the views were pretty sweet. I was only here for a night before my flight down to Puerto Natales and the gateway to Patagonia, as such all I did while here was get a haircut. It turns out my Spanish is not yet at ‚Äúdescribe a haircut‚Äù level, as such I have lost about 60% of my hair and have a solid grade 0 over most of the back of my head, let's hope it's not cold in the Magallanes and Chilean Antarctica region. ‚õÑÔ∏è

title: Torres del Paine
description: Spent a couple of days in Puerto Natales on my way back into Argentina. The town lies just south of the Torres del Paine national park and essentially acts as a staging ground for the famous 'W' & 'O' treks. I didn't have the spare days to do either of those unfortunately so instead I did a whirlwind driving tour around the park to see some of the most famous viewpoints, we were really lucky with the weather and the park itself was spectacular. The next stop is El Calafate to see the Perito Moreno glacier up close and then onto El Chalten for a few days of hiking in the mountains.

title: El Calafate
description: Awesome town. I assumed it would be a bit like Puerto Natales, just a staging ground for hiking, but it's a beautiful place in it's own right, ringed by mountains and lakes. The America del Sur is a great place to stay if you find yourself here as well, an amazing hostel with a great view over the surrounding scenery. A few of us got a bus to do a ~3 hour walk around the Perito Moreno glacier today, it's one of the few in the world that is expanding, which you can see in the form of massive shards breaking off as it grows accompanied by what sounds like bombs going off inside the glacier. Tomorrow we head to El Chalten for 4 days of hiking in some uncharacteristically congenial Patagonian weather. üòé

title: El Chalten
description: Capital Nacional del Trekking, and for good reason. El Chalten is quinessential Patagonia, with rolling foothills and steeper forested sections giving way to soaring cathedrals of rock, whichever way you head out of town you find crazy views. We spent the first couple days hiring some gear and doing some warm up hikes around town, as well as enjoying the last chance to feast on cheap Argentinian steak and red wine. The sunsets here are unbelievable. The highlight the 4 days there was 100% the overnight hike to see Fitz Roy at sunrise but I'll make a seperate post for that once I get a hold of everyones photos.

title: Fitz Roy
description: The idea to hike up and spend the night camping ready to see the sunrise on Fitz Roy was a great one (shout out to Lily) and soon after myself and Giulia tagged along we were joined by 4 more to make us a 7 strong gang. After hiring tents, sleeping bags and mats from town we started the 8-10km hike to the campsite under bright blue skies with no clouds and no wind (almost unheard of in Patagonia), a few sweaty hours later we arrived, put up our tents and put the ros√© in the nearby glacial stream to chill. Once we were set up we spent some time relazing and exploring the surrounding area to find a nice spot to watch the sun go down. Continued below...
additionalContent: After we had found a suitably beautiful spot away from the campsite we went back to the tents to enjoy some cold wine (out of washed out yoghurt cups), cheese and meats alongside our ever present feathered friend who we affectionately named a Cheagle (Chicken-Eagle). Later that night we wrapped up warm and, red wine in hand, returned to our selcuded little beach to watch the sun set over this amazing corner of Patagonia. We woke up at 3:45 to scramble up the last few kms to Laguna de Los Tres and settled down to watch the sun rise over Fitz Roy. It was cold, windy and beautiful. Then the weather did that Patagonia thing where it changes instantly and we were blown back down the mountains to pack up our tents, say our sad goodbyes and and head back to town. The next stop is Santiago which means ~12 hours of buses and ~6 hours of planes, woohoo!

title: Santiago
description: After saying goodbye to the mountains for a while it was time to head North, so I jumped on a bus to El Calafate & then on to Puerto Natales to have a last supper with the remaininng members of our Fitz Roy crew. The next day I caught a plane to Puerto Montt & then on to Santiago for 2 day pitstop. The city is massive so it's hard to get a real feel for it but the parts I have visited have been really nice, I espeically liked the arttisan village in Los Dominicos, which is a collection of 140 traditional and contemporary Chilean craft workshops. Where you can find all sorts of Mapuche & Chiloe art as well as hand made clothing, jewelery, pottery, copperwork, & traditional costumes (as well as excellent ceviche & pisco sours). Next stop is the Atacama for stargazing & the salt flats.

title: Atacama
description: The Atacama desert is one of the coolest and most alien places I've ever been, it's the second driest place on Earth (bonus point if you know the driest without Googling), clouds are a rarity and the stars at night are mindblowing. The town of San Pedro is an interesting little place which happend to be celebrating it's 45th birthday when I rolled into town, so that turned out to be a fun concert/party with the locals. After a night of too many Pisco sours, a group of us were up with the sun to meet our tour guide Samuel (legend), load up the Land Cruiser and head off towards Bolivia and the desert. The first day on the road was long and surprisingly arduous, that altitude is no joke! Continued below...
additionalContent: Gentle strolls around the Bolivian lagunas at 16,000 feet felt like a real effort and we were all feeling the strain after a while; however a dip in the hot springs, some lunch and a few ibuprofen for the altitude headaches soon sorted us out. Later that day, 13 hours after setting out, and in dire need of a good stretch, we reached our hostel for the night which was exactly as luxurious as a you might imagine a budget hostel in the middle of the Atacama desert to be. But the bedrooms and the food were warm so I counted myself lucky. Tomorrow we cross over into the Altiplano and make our way towards the salt flats.

title: Salt Flats
description: After the first day we had acclimatised to the altitude so no more headaches & less shortness of breath. Our first stop was just an hour down the road and gave us a chance to act like kids and scale some interstingly shaped rocks. See if you can guess what the first three rocks below are meant to be. The next stop was an area I named the Hidden Valley of the Llamas. After not seeing anything approaching a trickle of fresh water for a few days we came to an amazing series of valleys with streams and fresh water lagoons running through them and the first grass/moss/green stuff we'd seen. As the name suggests it was packed with llamas, giant chinchilla looking things as well as a whole host of other creatures great and small. Continued below...
additionalContent: After that we headed for the Ananaconda Canyon (named for the winding river) and found the clouds lit up with rainbow colours, which made for a great photo op for us & Samuel. Then it was finally time to head for the Salt Flats with one quick stop at the first bar we'd seen in days for some beers brewed with all sorts of novel ingredients (coca leaves & cactus were favourites). We spent the night in a hotel where the walls were made from salt and the showers were blissfully warm before a 4am wakeup to watch the sun rise over the salt flats. Next we drove across the flats to Isla de Incahuasi to see the cacti and have some breakfast, then it was time to take the customary forced perspective shots on the flats. The last stop before heading back to San Pedro & the flight to Santiago was Uyuni itself to see the train graveyard and have some lunch (veggie soup & grilled llama is now a firm favourite lunchtime combo). As with all these sorts of trips the people you spend it with play a massive part and I was yet again lucky to find a great group of people to spend 4 days crammed inside a Land Cruiser with, so shoutout to any of Samuel's Salt Squad if your reading this! I'm currently in an airport hotel before the flight to NZ at midnight, so this is the end of the South American chapter & the next post will be from Auckland! See you there üá≥üáø!

title: Auckland
description: After a night in Santiago enjoying pisco sours and the hotel sauna & pool I jumped on my midnight flight to NZ. The flight wasn't too bad and I arrived in Auckland at 5am, 13 hours after taking off. Unfortunately I couldn't check into my hostel until 3pm so I spent the day scooting around town seeing some of the sites (including a practically deserted museum). At 3pm I realised I didn't understand time zones as I had actually booked the hostel for the day before so I would have been well within my rights to check in anyway. Regardless, after unpacking I promptly fell asleep for 7 hours, waking up at 1am and supremely fucking up my body clock. Thankfully the hostel bar sells espresso martinis.

title: The Shire
description: Roadtrip Day 1! [Hint, you can click the globe to zoom in while I'm in NZ]. The first stop after picking up the campervan was a visit to the Hobbiton movie set, I was actually kind of blown away by how beautiful and real it all is, I expected it to feel like a filmset but it really doesn't. They've built and furnished 2 complete hobbit holes either side of the Gamgee residence and the detail is amazing, you can see me sitting in grandpa Proudfoot's chair below. After a quick pie & a brew at the Green Dragon I hit the road and headed for Lake Arapuni, finding the campsite all but deserted I got a cassoulet on the cooker and broke out a beer. This morning I took a dip in the lake (photo evidence included) and am now heading for the Forgotten World Highway.

title: Forgotten World
description: I am genuinely surprised that New Zealand doesn't have the highest rate of road fatalities in the world. Not because of the drivers or the road quality, but because it is completely impossible to keep your eyes on the road. Today I drove for about 4 hours from Pureora to Whanganui, mainly along the Forgotten World Highway and I almost crashed about 3 times because I was staring at the amazing views. In those 4 hours I drove through Dartmoor; then the foothills of Switzerland, the jungles of Hawaii and finally arrived in Cornwall. The scenery was just obscene and I was one of the only people on the road to enjoy it. Unfortunately my GoPro is refusing to turn on so no pictures from the drive. I also learned a couple of things. Continued below...
additionalContent: Attention: If you are my mum, this is a good point to stop reading. The first thing I learned is that a road being classed as a state highway in NZ is no guarentee of a smooth or even a paved surface. The second thing I learned is that my campervan has no traction control or ABS. The third thing I learned is that fitting a massive water tank, a fridge and all the electrical setup in the very back of a Toyota Estima makes it very tail happy on gravel and other loose surfaces. Combine all this with the fact that the car gives a panicked beep when it detects that it's going sideways and you have a fantasic rallycross game. I genuinely don't think I've laughed or smiled while driving a vehichle as much as I did today, although the roads down some of the gorges did make me shit myself. Regardless I lived to tell the tale and to find a tiny little out of the way campground (again deserted) which had an awesome natural amphitheate about an hours hike upriver. This place has hot showers but I still might try the river first tomorrow, something about a cold water swim in nature really sets you up well for the day. After that I'll be back on the rally circuit for a while as I head West towards The Surf Highway and hopefully some sunshine.

title: Surf Highway
description: Pretty slow and relaxed day. I headed West towards New Plymouth, stopping to take a couple of snaps of Mt. Taranaki on the way which looks like a slightly more rugged version of Mt. Fuji. Once I got to the coast I found the tallest thing I could to climb (monkey brain) and took in the view. After a surpringly steep clamber up Mount Moturoa I jumped back in the van and headed down the coast to grab some lunch at a vineyard on the ocean (great view and great seafood) and then continued down the Surf Highway to ≈åpunake where I was able to enjoy some rare sunshine with a beer before the sun went down.

title: Tararua
description: I was up before the sun today for a morning dip in the ocean and some breakfast before I got on the road heading East away from the Taranaki peninsula and towards Tararua Forest Park. After a quick stop for supplies and to do some laundry in Palmerston North I made it to Holdsworth Lodge at the foot of the park and got set up. As I'd made the trip in such good time and the sun was shining I decided to go on one of the longer hikes that start from the lodge. Unfortunately the peaks in the park are pretty much perpetually wreathed in cloud so I didn't stay dry for long and after a couple hours the higher ground became a bog so I bravely turned around in favour of a dip in the river, fajitas and some Pinot Grigio from the vineyard I visted the day before.

title: Wellington
description: Up early today in order to get down to Wellington in time to meet up with a couple of old friends, in fact both former roommates of mine. Hard to believe that it's been 6 years since we've seen each other, it felt like no time at all and it was amazing to sit and laugh with them again at brunch just like we used to do at Tooloulous in Banff. Later that day I crossed Oriental Bay and headed for the Wainuiomata Coast. I clearly didn't learn my lesson about unpredictable weather and hiking because I got caught out and thoroughly drenched in a storm halfway through a 3 hour hike. Thankfully the place I was staying had hot showers, and again was completely deserted, it's like I'm the only one who finds any of these places, kind of strange but no complaints.

title: Pohangina
description: From down on the south coast I headed up towards the center of the north island via the Tararua mountain pass & the aptly named Manawat≈´ Scenic Route. My plan of avoiding all the highways has been working out beautifully so far as the scenery has been amazing. Some of the supposedly two lane tracks through the gorges have been a touch hairy but for the most part you never see anyone else using them (I probably wouldn't either if I was in my own car and had to pay to repair my suspension every few weeks). I stayed in the little community of Pohangina, again I was the only person in residence at the campsite, aside from a thousnad kiwi's in the surrounding woods and a few sheep across the other side of the valley.

title: Napier
description: Today was a long old drive back on the Manawat≈´ Scenic Route across a forest covered mountain range known as the Ruahine. Eventually I arrived in Napier for a fuel stop and to resupply the fridge. After exploring around the town for a while I headed up to WaipƒÅtiki beach on the recommendation of a girl in the coffee shop I visited. It was a lovely place but the weather was closing in and threatening to rain so I decided to skip the swim and head straight for Lake Tutira where I set up for the night after a hike which got cut short due to me completely losing the trail in the rolling fog & cloud at the top of the surrounding hills (see the photo that looks like Dartmoor). The next morning woke with a perfect blue sky and a mirror lake which I ruined with my morning swim before I headed North towards more lakes and away from any sort of civilization.

title: Waikaremoana
description: Probably my favourite place so far in NZ. Getting here is a bit of an effort. The only road to the lake is about 3 hours and only about 10% of it is paved, as such that means hardly anyone makes the journey and as a result there wasd only one other car in sight when I bounced and slid my way down to the lakeside. As you can see below the weather and the water were perfect, it even had a little island to swim out to (once the black swans were ousted). The occupants of the other car turned out to be a young Aussie bloke and his two little lads who were really good craic and apparently very adept at fishing. So after I'd built a fire with some of the driftwood around the shore we had fresh trout and a few beers to round out a pretty perfect road trip day. I kicked off the next day with a sunset swim out to Fanning Island (formally Black Swan Isle) and then hit the road heading for the Bay of Plenty.

title: Tauranga
description: After a couple hours back on the rally circuits from Lake Waikaremoana it was on to Rotorua, a town renowned for it's geothermal activity and maori culture, I didn't take too many pics today for whatever reason, after Waikaremoana the lake seemed a bit tame. As a result I decided to catry on North to the city of Tauranga just south of the Coromandel peninsula. I spent the night in a suburb called Mount Maunganui, named for the towering volcano at the end of the beach. It's a beautiful spot full of great bars and restaurants, the place I stayed was right on the beach with a pool and thermal bath next door. Tomorrow's plan is to hike the volcano and catch some waves üèÑ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è.

title: Mount Maunganui
description: Well today was pretty ace, after a reasonably early wake up I made my way up Mount Maunganui in the sunshine, turns out the UV rating was 18 (I never realised the scale went above 10) so I was slathered in enough suncream to drown a small dog. After 45 minutes of steep steps I had sweated all that off and reached the peak which gave great views over the beach and the surrounding areas. On the way back I found a place to rent a surfboard and cooled off in the water for a while (still shit at surfing) before a great lunch at The General cafe just down the road from the beach. Once the clouds came out I decided to make my move North towards the Coromandel peninsula, I also looked at the date for the first time in a while and decided to crack on the Christmas playlist for a bit, 2 songs in and I drove through Bethlehem which made me laugh but I didn't bother to stop as I've heard there's no room at any of their inn's.

title: Coromandel
description: I spent last night roughly in the center of the Coromandel peninsula on the banks of the Waiwawa River. After a morning dip in the surprisingly fast flowing water I got on the road early as I had a long drive to get to the very Northern tip of the peninsula, and what a drive! It's definitely a contender for the most scenic road so far, a winding gravel path bordered all the way North by the Hauraki Gulf glistening in the sunshine. The only downside were the multitude of caravans slowing down proceedings, but they were happy enough to let you pass when the road would allow. Arriving at the beach in Port Jackson it's clearly a popular spot to spend the festive season and probably the busiest place I've stayed so far, I got in a hike and a swim before the sun disappeared and the heavens opened for a couple of hours, just like Christmas back home!

title: Christmas
description: So after my customary morning swim in the Coromandel I headed back down the coast road to Auckland to return the van and check in to the LyLo for Christmas. A group of 4 of us spent Christmas Eve in a vaguely Irish pub by the harbour drinking with a great live band drinking Baby Guinness and singing along to the renditions of Christmas classics until the early morning. On the day itself we took a ferry to Waiheke Island and had a picnic on the beach once the sun came out. It turns out NZ doesn't sell alcohol on Xmas Day unless you buy a meal (which felt reminiscent of covid) so we then went to a beach bar and had one seafood platter and some chips between us, which allowed us to buy a few pitchers of beer, some champagne and about 15 teapots full of cocktails, #kiwiMaths. Boxing day was an early wake up for family facetime before heading to the airport to fly to Christchurch to start the South Island leg of the roadtrip.

title: Lake Tekapo
description: Boxing Day was a mad scramble to pick up the van, find petrol and do some shopping before the shops closed, then I headed to Lake Ellesmere for the night. The next day the trip began for real and I set out for Lake Tekapo and the Aoraki Mackenzie International Dark Sky Reserve, the weather was awful most of the way but the Dark Sky Reserve seems to have a cloud barrier set up somehow, as soon as you reach the lakes the sky is cloudless and almost as blue as the lakes. The viewpoints around the lake and the famous church were absolutely rammed with tourists but there's a gravel track on the East side of the lake which runs it's length and is completely empty, so after a half hour of testing the rally capabilities of the new van I stopped for some lunch and then went for a very scenic swim to cool off before heading for the overnight stop near Lake Pukaki (lol) which has Mount Cook looming over it's North shore and might be even more scenic than it's more famous borther.

title: Milford Sound
description: Next on the flying tour of the South Island was Milford Sound. My plan was to drive the whole 6 hours in one hit but the weather near the sound was crap so I decided to stay the night in Kingston (a tiny little lake town about halfway) and enjoyed an afternoon of sunshine and lake swims. I didn't realise that the lake was glacier fed and thus absolutely freezing until I dived in, my testicals are due to re-emerge any day now. The next day I headed for the sound, or Piopiotahi in MƒÅori which sounds way cooler. Man is that place wet. Not sure I've been as soaked as that in a few years (really makes me wish I didn't leave my only item of waterproof clothing in Mendoza), but the rain is worth it because it feeds the hundreds of waterfalls which cascade into the sound and make it such an amazing place to be. That being said as soon as the boat tour was done I escaped back to the clear skies as quickly as I could.

title: Queenstown NYE
description: This is one I've been looking forward to for a long time. New Zealand's Mecca for adreneline junkies, birthplace of bungy jumping and all round center for good vibes. It reminds me a bit of Banff in a way, so I of course absolutely love it. Maybe it's seeing this season's skis in the shop windows or the people skating around with crates of beer in hand, whatever it is, I like it. First thing's first it's now been >12 weeks since I got my eyes lasered so I can bungy jump, as such that's was where I immediately headed. It's funny, standing on the bridge in a harness chatting with the group of girls next to me I really thought I'd be nervous and wanting to not do it, but I felt fine. Until I was actually stood on the ledge. That feeling when your toes are over the edge and there is nothing below you but fresh air all the way down to the river is a unique one to say the least, I think I said ‚ÄúWow, this is a nightmare‚Äù to the bloke who'd hooked me in. Continued below...
additionalContent: I'm sure he's heard much worse so his response was a dry chuckle followed by ‚Äú5..4..3..2..1‚Äù at which point you have to overcome every fibre of your being telling you to turn around and walk away and instead throw yourself off. For NYE I met up with John one of my Auckland Christmas friends and a couple of girls we'd met and we went on a pub crawl with about a thousand other people which was very boozy and very fun, I didn't manage to take a single photo the entire night but apparently they are going to release some taken during the evening so I'm absolutely not looking forward to seeing any of those. Either way, I started the New Year with a hangover curing dip in Lake Wakatipu and hit the road early to get to Franz Josef for some skydiving! P.s. My mobile internet no longer works so don't expect speedy responses until I finish the roadtrip.

title: Franz Josef
description: Most of my New Years Day was spent getting from Queenstown to Wanaka via the Crown Range Road which was a pretty beautiful even for someone as hungover as I was. After a quick lunch in Wanaka I had to keep going to get close to Franz Josef for the night so I could be up early for the flight. The flight itself was on a little ~10 seater single prop aircraft with 2 rows of seats all facing towards the back of the plane. The views on the way up of the coast and the ocean were amazing but the views of the glaciers and the Southern Alps once we broker through the clouds were even better. Because we were going to 16,500ft (amazingly, roughly the same height as we were when we drove across the desert in Bolivia) we had to strap on oxygen masks for the last few minutes before the doors opened. Because your first jump is tandem, there's not a whole lot you have to do for the jump itself, just shuffle towards the door and wait for the guy your strapped to to throw himself out. Continued below...
additionalContent: In that sense it's much less difficult than the bungy jump was as you don't really have much control. It's also WAY more enjoyable, the bungy is over almost before you realise what's going on. Not so much with skydiving. About 3 seconds after you leave the aircraft you hit terminal velocity (~120mph) which means from 16,500ft you freefall for about a minute before you pull the cord. That feeling of freefalling is so unique and exhilarating that I still get the feeling of jelly legs just writing about it now a few days later. Once you pull the cord and adjust yourself your tandem instructor will give you control of the chute for a while which is an amazingly free feeling, akin to skiing in really deep powder where you can't feel the bottom, I can absolutely see the appeal and how people get hooked on the combo of adreline rush in the freefall combined with floating on air after, would definitely recommend and would definitely do again!

title: Whites Bay
description: A few hours after we had done our jump the clouds rolled in (and stopped the rest of the jumps that day), I took that as a good signal to head inland away from the damn sandflies and towards better weather. The first day I got as far as an old gold mining town called Reefton where I spent the night by a quick little river with more Kea inhabitants than humans. The next morning I chased away the last ramining kea who was nibbling my windscreen wipers and set off for the East coast where the sunshine was, ending up in a lovely little place called White's Bay, a seculded shallow bay with a sandy beach surrounding it and plenty of scenic hikes to stretch the legs after a long time sat in the drivers seat.

title: Cape Farewell
description: The plan for the next few days was to jaunt about Nelson & the Abel Tasman national park, swimming, kayaking and sunbathing. Unfortunately the weather had other plans, calling for 1 nice day followed by a few days of rain. As such I decided to skip over Nelson and head straight up the coast to the most Northerly point on the South Island, aptly named Cape Farewell to enjoy the sun and scenery before the rain came. What I didn't plan on was everyone else on the South Island doing the same thing and as a result every campsite, scenic stopping point or patch of grass in someone's garden being booked out. Thankfully I found a very nice lady from Birmingham called Nicky who ran a campsite and carved me out a patch of ground to park the van for the night, legend.
